title: Stripped request header = 500 error
body:
Norton (and some other security software or browser addons) strip the referrer header of requests.

If I disable referrers, (network.http.sendRefererHeader) in about:config in Firefox at least, it will consistently always throw the 500 error.

title: invalid array in lib/router/route.js#L52
body:
since line 52 is `params = this.params = []`

line 65 `params[key.name] = val;` is invalid

the result is something like this `[ var1: 'test', var2: '123', var3: 'lastvar' ]`

when it should be `{ var1: 'test', var2: '123', var3: 'lastvar' }`

or `[ 'test', '123', 'lastvar' ]`
( aka `[ 0: 'test', 1: '123', 2: 'lastvar' ]` )

what is there is not a valid use of that data type.

title: Undocumented: `req.csrfToken()`
body: With the latest express, I get the message "req.session._csrf is deprecated, use req.csrfToken([callback]) instead". However, I can't seem to find any documentation on this method on either of the docs sites for express or connect. Perhaps it's another place, but it probably shouldn't be deprecated without something in the docs for the replacement.

title: bodyParser should separate file handling, or ship with clearer documentation, due to possible security flaw and widespread use
body:
bodyParser opens up a possible security risk by receiving and storing files automatically. Due to its widespread use as a general form processor, many or most users may not realize that default behavior is to accept files and store them in a tmp folder.

Re https://github.com/senchalabs/connect/issues/871
and
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/1673

title: decodeURIComponent fails on certain non-regexp routes containing a "*".
changed behaviour - posted object (whic is converted to array) is indexed incorrectly
body:
Hi,

in previous versions of express, posted objects were converted to array (I don't know if each time, but in more 'complex' posts that happened). For example, if you posted object with data at index 100, it was converted on server side to array, with 100 empty inserts and posted insert at index 100. Although it this was not ok it at least worked.
But now with latest update (maybe it broke before), this is not working any more.

how to reproduce:
1. route
   app.post('/test', function(req, res){
   console.log(req.body.blah[50]);
   console.log(req.body.blah);
   });
2. post
   from client, do a post (I'm using jquery for test):
   $.post('/test', {blah: {50: [{b: 1},{a:2}]}})

RESULT:
express v3.3.5, console logs

undefined
[ [ { b: '1' }, { a: '2' } ]]

problem is, that 'blah' object is converted into array and not indexed properly any more, which makes our code break.

express v3.0.0-rc5, console logs:

[ { b: '1' }, { a: '2' } ]
[,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,....., [ { b: '1' }, { a: '2' } ]]

this at least works, if you expect data at certain index (in this case 50).

title: Improved variable names and updated comments for better clarity of example
How do sessions work in express?
body:
When I log into my website that uses express I am issued a cookie that contains a session id.  Something like below:

```
connect.sid = s%3AcZVFZJ3VVAFxY41XluwzsTwN.pKfYsxVqXwS51N53kc4tTvasKRb5fO%2FXxHniNMfsW%2FA
```

I've noticed that when I log out and log back in this session id does not change, but that my access to protected portions of the site is denied when logged out and granted when logged back in as you would expect.

I had assumed that when I logged out that the session id would be destroyed and a new one created when I logged back in.  Based on the above behavior it seems like this assumption is incorrect.

Can anyone explain what is happening on the back end when I log in/out and why the same session id works after I log out and then back in?

title: Can't stop express from putting HTTP status text in the HTTP body (no option to send empty body)
body:
In some responses, we don't want to send a body at all, like a http 200.. If there's text in the body,clients automatically try to parse it as json and their code breaks..

There's no option/way to set an empty body in express. Since when calling `res.send(200)` express automatically puts the status message into the body which is redundant

title: res.sendfile() tries to send the file even after a response has been sent, on the event of a socket error
body:
res.sendfile() tries to send the file even after a error response has been sent on the event of a socket error resulting in "Error: Can't set headers after they are sent.".

**Cause**

send.js which handles the sending of the file is not aware about the socket error on the req object.

**Note**

In the current setup, adding a socket error handler in send.js will result in another socket error handler being fired after the one in response.js is fired.

view cache improve
body:
Hi

I am using the nodejs/express(version 3.2) to develop a website, I want to place the views in different modules, so before render a file in route each time, i reset app.set('views') to new dir, but the cache cause the result error;

if i change the source code at line 479 & 496 in application.js

app.render = function(name, options, fn){
  // primed cache
  if (opts.cache) view = cache[name];     // root+name line 479

```
// prime the cache
if (opts.cache) cache[name] = view;   // root+name line 496
```

the cache name was changed to "this.get('views')+'/'+name ",

My wiews will be ok.

so I suggest you change the code in next version.

 Thanks very much!

Best Regards

title: Don't add charset to Content-Type header when using res.jsonp()
body: The charset was removed from `res.json()` in visionmedia/express#1631 - this PR removes it from `res.jsonp` too.

title: Ability to install a pre-controller middleware that is always invoked
body:
It would be nice to be able to install middleware that gets fired immediately before invoking the route (but after the route is matched). It would be very similar to app.param(), but it would always be invoked (e.g. app.preroute(fn)).

People could use it for whatever, but the common case, at least for me, would be to load the path's dependencies asynchronously.

Most examples out there handle http://example.com/:foo?bar=baz by fetching the logged in user during auth deserialization, then loading :foo via app.param, then loading baz in the controller. I find that more often than not, the viewer, :foo, and baz are mutually exclusive and io bound, and thus should be loaded asynchronously. Something like app.preroute() would facilitate this.

The way I handle it right now is to not fetch during auth deserialization, never use app.param, and every route looks like `app.<method>(<path>, load, <controller>)`. It'd be preferable to just do `app.preroute(load)` once, and it might encourage others to be wary of the fact that middleware gets run serially!

title: daemon
body: hi, can someone tell me how to run a express application as a daemon?

title: session duplication when serving local jquery 1.9.x to chrome
body:
If you have a locally served jquery 1.9.x Chrome will make a request for jquery.min.map if its debug tools tab is open. This request doesn't appear in the network tab and also doesn't send any session cookies your server may have previously assigned, so express creates a new session for that request. The upshot is that for **every page refresh** you get a newly orphaned session.

```
http://blog.jquery.com/2013/01/09/jquery-1-9-rc1-and-migrate-rc1-released/#sourcemaps
```

If you add a filter for jquery.min.map before the express.session() directive to return, say, a 404 then this prevents the problem but if other libraries start doing these .map files then things could get messy.

I wanted to get this information out there to save someone the pain of debugging this.
What's a better solution?

title: Added res.vary()
body: Fixes #1682

title: Feature Request: Dynamic Routing
body:
I think it would greatly benefit the API to have exposed methods for removing and adding routes during runtime.

I can see a lot of use cases for adding/removing new routes based on general CMS housekeeping. Although, at the moment, you can technically remove/add routes by hijacking the map object, there are no certainties that future versions of Express will not break core functionality: functionality which, IMO, could be at the heart of any CMS built around Express.

Is the lack of this feature due to performance concerns in re-routing, an aim to keep Express as a loose framework, or simply an oversight of the possibilities?

I would be happy to have a crack at implementation but thought I should first put the stink out and see if anybody gags...

Thanks,
Shennan

title: express.static() dumps stacktraces for 403 forbidden even when showstack and dumpexceptions are false
body:
This example program (using express 3.3.4) dumps a full stack trace to the HTTP client, exposing full path names and so on, when the client sends a GET for a static path containing "..":

``` javascript
var express = require('express');
var app = express();
app.use(express.errorHandler({dumpExceptions: false, showStack: false}));
app.use('/public', express.static(__dirname + '/public'));
app.listen(3000);
```

Request:

``` shell
% curl http://localhost:3000/public/../
Error: Forbidden
    at SendStream.error (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/lib/send.js:145:16)
    at SendStream.pipe (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/lib/send.js:310:52)
    at Object.staticMiddleware [as handle] (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/static.js:84:8)
    at next (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
    at next (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:192:9)
    at Object.expressInit [as handle] (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/lib/middleware.js:30:5)
    at next (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
    at Object.query [as handle] (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/query.js:44:5)
    at next (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
    at Function.app.handle (/private/tmp/express-test/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:198:3)
```

title: Cannot get req.query from a route with a param - is this intentional? Why?
res.method()?
req.params is overwritten when multiple routes match a URL
body:
Sample code: https://gist.github.com/dymonaz/6131160

Expected:
Existing req.params not to be destroyed... Or maybe a brand new req should be created/cloned for each route handler to enforce the fact that we shouldn't reuse req.params if we shouldn't.

Workaround:
Create a local copy of req.params for every matching route inside the handler function...

Culprit:
`req.params = route.params;`
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/router/index.js#L115

Background:
We're using the catch-all route for some sophisticated error handling. I can't recall the details exactly why we couldn't use a simple middleware - but there _was_ a good reason :)

title: Added UTF-8 charset default to res.json method.
body:
`res.json` malfunctioned when JSON contained UTF-8 characters. For example

```
res.json({ 'ąčęėįšųūž': 'ąčęėįšųūž' })
```

would be treated in Chrome like

```
{
  "Ä…ÄÄ™Ä—Ä¯Å¡Å³Å«Å¾": "Ä…ÄÄ™Ä—Ä¯Å¡Å³Å«Å¾"
}
```

It can be fixed by setting charset BEFORE setting content type so that `Content-Type` header would be set to `application/json; charset=utf-8` instead of `application/json`. This is pretty much the same what `res.send` does with a string - `Content-Type` header also gets the UTF-8 charset: `text/html; charset=utf-8`.

title: front page devoid of facts
body:
I'm talking about this page:   http://expressjs.com/

When I got to your front page, I wanted some big-picture answers.  says "flexible node.js web application framework" - ok it uses node.js.  But it's a Web Application Framework.  so is Drupal, WebLogic, RoR, .NET, apache, jQuery, Backbone.js, nginx, and Python.  But all of those are very diverse - in many cases complementary.  You need to nail down some specifics that tell me what to expect (and whether to bother to download it and try it out).

What does express have in it?  "A robust set of features for building single and multi-page, and hybrid web applications"  The same is true for Drupal, WebLogic, RoR, .NET, apache, jQuery, Backbone.js, nginx, and Python.  But the way you do it, and your capabilities, vary from one of those to another; eg Drupal must run on top of PHP which often runs on top of Apache.  You can build your website on raw apache, is that like express?  Are there tons of forms to fill out like Drupal?  I'm getting no such answers from the front page; it's all marketing fluff.

Try something like these

express takes the place of apache because it's the direct web server, streamlining something.  It provides an environment where you can use (what languages) with (smarty? mustache?) to generate your web pages.

Using Node.js's network interfaces, express serves web pages directly on the net, without the need for a lumbering server like Apache.  a

what else I dunno I just started on it.  Needs specifics. Your market is programmers,  probably not brainless suits.

title: app.path() public method
body: Hello, I'm requesting that the [app.path()](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/application.js#L261) private method be made public. I think it is a common use case to generate a URL based on the mount point of an app, which this method facilitates. By keeping it private and hidden, it encourages ugly workarounds.

title: Add application setting to disable ETag (again)
body:
It's updated to upstream duplicate of the old Pull Request #1421.

Old Pull Request description:

> Add application setting app.disable('etag'); to disable ETag. Manual ETag addition via res.set('etag', 'somestring);' still works.
> 
> Please, check this feature.
> 
> Btw, it's my first experience in Express and JS BDD, so, please, if there are any issues or mistakes (for ex., I am not sure about proper spec placement), let me know, maybe I'll can fix 'em.
> 
> Thanks!

@visionmedia, sorry for such a long delay, I totally forgot about this pull request and that I need to sync it with upstream. I hope everything is good now.

title: Update commander.
Default location for views uses cwd() which is a security risk
body:
Hi,

Currently express is using cwd() as default way of finding a view. If developer is unaware of this, she might install the application in production and depending on where the process was started from application can either break or even worse start serving out wrong files, which poses a security risk.

Would it be possible to remove this default and require developers to specify the views or application's root explicitly rather then assuming the application root is at cwd()?

In production it is simply never the case, since any daemon tool would set cwd = '/'.

I refer to this line:
this.set('views', process.cwd() + '/views'); 

Thanks,
Denis

title: add Router.all() method
body:
Similar to app.all() but specifically for attaching handlers to all
methods under a standalone router. This is useful for isolating routers
that require "middleware" like features for all routes managed by the
router.

title: Default OPTIONS Not Functioning as Expected
body: For some reason, attempting to make an `OPTIONS` request responds with a 404 status code, and "Cannot OPTIONS /route." My understanding is that Express should automatically respond with the defined routes at the specified path, and defer to custom-defined `options` routes. This occurs regardless of the request mechanism, and across many server configurations.

Something like (or some variation of it):

``` js

```

title: Fix typo in app.param comment
express.limit() can be exploited
body:
The middleware, express.limit(), for limiting the size of file you can upload can be exploited.  Since express.limit() works by checking the headers for the file size, you can work around it.  If you modify the headers and set 'content-type' to below the size limit, you will be able to upload the file.  I used the python requests library to do this, but I am sure there are simpler ways.  

Here is the code for the express.limit middleware: https://github.com/senchalabs/connect/blob/master/lib/middleware/limit.js#L31

And here is how I exploited it in python:
requests.post('http://localhost/upload',files={'filename':open('mutt.txt','r')},headers={'content-length':'1'})

title: res.links() should support multiple calls
body: and append

title: res.vary()
Pass other things than path prefix as first argument to 'use'.
body:
As stated in the documentation, this piece of code:
`app.use('/static', express.static(__dirname + '/public'));`
will pass all requests starting with '/static' through the static middleware.

Could it be possible to send in other configuration options as a first argument? One example would be if the request has a specific header. I'd like to configure express so that all requests that has a header `Accept: application/json` passes through a certain chain of middleware since (in my application) this means that the request is for data in the database. Requests that accept `text/html` could go through other middleware since I know that this is another type of request that serves a different purpose.

Today I have to prefix all my database requests with a certain path. Or is there another way to achieve what I want?

title: Settings do not get inherited from the parent of a parent of a mounted application and cannot be retrieved ahead of time
body:
When mounting an express app from another app, the first (child) app must be created before it ever has any knowledge of the existence of the parent, meaning the settings do not get inherited until after it has been mounted. This makes it difficult if there is other functionality that must be set up ahead of time that requires information contained in the settings of its parent. One possible solution I thought of would be to use the 'mount' event and get the setting then, however due to the design of my application, I have an express app mount an express app which mounts an express app and therefore the system doesn't propagate the settings down the chain to the most deep express app, and the mount event is actually too early to know the settings. 

Would you consider adding something to future versions of express to deal with this issue?

title: status 200 when res.json(undefined)
body:
Hi, there!
I start use express 3.x after 2.x and i discover that `res.json()` call returns http status 200 instead of 204 (at express 2.x). Is it bug or feature?)

title: Wrong content length causing message to be truncated
Replace Cookie Parser

Hi

I like the way sessions work inside express but I do not want to use a cookie since I'm building a REST API. At the moment I pass an access token inside the header (similar to a cookie I know but I still want to separate them). Is it possible to use something other than the cookie parser for sessions?

title: Script to automate setting+tagging version name
body:
Hello,

At the moment, while Express version 3.3.2 and version 3.3.3 are out in the npm registry, those versions are not tagged in the Git repository. Tags may be "annoying to maintain" (please note the official quote ;-) ) when they are not part of an automated process.

So here I propose you a script to ease version name bump and tag.

Please note that this script enforces the SemVerTag sub-spec (because this is the convention I use for the projects I work on and from where this script is coming):
version names are like "3.3.4" (semver compliant) and that tag names are like "v3.3.4".

Also note that recently the SemVerTag sub-spec has been removed from the SemVer spec but only to have the SemVer reach the widest possible consensus https://github.com/mojombo/semver.org/issues/42 but SemVerTag is still relevant and useful cf. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2006265/is-there-an-standard-naming-convention-for-git-tags

If following SemVerTag is not what you want, I can modify the script so that version names and version tags are of the same form. Please let me know.

Best, (and thank you for Express!)

Is there a way to ensure that all files sent in a request are deleted automatically once the request has been handled?

title: jsonp callback including '
body:
Hi,

I'm using [esri-leaflet](https://github.com/Esri/esri-leaflet) which is consuming [this](http://citybikes-ags.aws.af.cm/rest/services/citibikenyc/FeatureServer/0/query?f=json) ExpressJS service I've written. It uses jsonp. Here's an example of the `callback` parameter:

`L.esri._callbacks['callback_9moie5.ef6vpshsemi']`

Now, ExpressJS explicitly strips out the `'` characters from that, which causes the esri-leaflet client to fail when it gets the response from my service.

Before I submit a pull request on ExpressJS to fix this [here](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/response.js#L238):

``` JavaScript
var cb = callback.replace(/[^\[\]\w$.]/g, '');
```

with

``` JavaScript
var cb = callback.replace(/[^\[\]\w$.'"]/g, '');
```

…is there a reason that quotes are being stripped out - should I instead get esri-leaflet to change the callback they provide? Other services (not written in ExpressJS) do not strip this out.

Cheers,

Nick.

title: Add support for multiple view directories
body:
Adds support for multiple view directories. Backwards compatible and to add multiple directories you just go `app.set("views", ["views", "views2"]);`. This is especially handy for modular applications that have multiple view directories.

Sorry about the previous closed pull request, never made one before and I screwed things up.

title: Adds support for multiple view directories
body: Adds support for multiple view directories. Backwards compatible and allows you to go `app.set("views", ["views", "views2"]);`. This is especially handy for modular applications that have multiple view directories.

title: How to bypass middleware callbacks and pass control to last callback  in a route?
body:
I have three middleware callbacks in a route. I want to bypass middleware callbacks and pass control to  last callback.

A example code

``` javascript
var middleware = [loadData, loadForum, loadThread];

app.get('/forum/:fid/thread/:tid', middleware, finalMethod);
```

**Use case**:  If first callback `loadData` enters into strange case like failing to load data. I would like by pass `loadForum` and `loadThread` middleware callbacks and pass control to last route callback `finalMethod`.

If  `next()` is called in middleware callback,  it will go to next callback.
If I understand correctly, `next('route')` will go to other route given in argument of `next` method, not to last route callback.

How to bypass middleware callbacks and pass control to last callback?

I am trying to avoid deep nested functions in methods. So I think to set middleware in routes, each nesting functions can be splitted into each method and setting it's result in `request` object. So that next middleware method can be access its result through `request` object.
Is this good way to handle deep nested functions or any other good way to do this?

title: Fixes typo in index.js vhost example
npm warnings during install
body:
Hi,

I'm on a mission on removing misc npm warnings during install. I'm aware of that they aren't crucial, but I want to avoid the broken window theory. If there are 20 warnings and number 21 comes along, it will never get noticed. If there are zero warnings and one show up, it will get noticed.

Anyway, I noticed the following warnings which I can't fix since I can't find any repositories on github:

``` bash
npm WARN package.json range-parser@0.0.4 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json methods@0.0.1 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json methods@0.0.1 No readme data.
npm WARN package.json fresh@0.1.0 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json send@0.1.0 No repository field. (PR sent for this one)
npm WARN package.json cookie-signature@1.0.1 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json pause@0.0.1 No repository field.
npm WARN package.json bytes@0.2.0 No repository field.
```

Thanks
/Magnus

title: Fatal memory leak witn HTTP range request
body:
Hi guys! I was using the <audio> tag to play a mp3 file hosted on my express server (the mp3 file was simply placed in my 'public' folder), but node will crash with fatal memory leak.

Suppose the mp3 file is http://mysite/foo.mp3 (~2MB), when I open a HTML with a <audio src='http://mysite/foo.mp3' autoplay> tag, the server-end memory usage will increase up to 100%... But if I directly download the file, everything's OK. After some searching and testing, I found that the <audio> tag is sending multiple ranged requests, node then behaves strange(keeping all requests and data chunks in memory?). It happens on remote servers, while localhost works well.  

It seems to be a bug in the 'http' module, but maybe express can handle it with some work-around?

title: res.json only support code 200 when body is undefined
body:
I'm building a REST API and only need to send error codes from the server. Messages are being handled by the client.

res.json(200); works.

res.json(304); does not. 304 becomes the body with the status being changed to 200.

res.json(304, {}); works.

title: Supports JSONP in .send or .format
body:
Thanks to the new `res.jsonp()` method I can easily unify json and jsonp response.

But when an app uses `res.send()` by default, it supports json. How do I add support to jsonp without explicitly doing dirty codes like this `if (querystring.callback) ...`?
